{{Infobox mythical creature |name = Lava bear |AKA = Sand lapper and dwarf grizzly |image = Lava Bear, Oregon Sportsman, 1917.jpg |image_size = 275px |caption = Lava bear specimen exhibited in 1917 |Grouping = [[Cryptid]] |Sub_Grouping = Undersized variation of known species (''[[Ursus americanus]]'') |Country = [[United States]] |Region = South central Oregon |Habitat = [[High Desert (Oregon)|High desert]] lava beds |First_Reported = 1917 |Last_Reported = 1934 |Similar_creatures = [[American black bear]] }}
The '''lava bear''' (also known as '''sand lapper''', '''dwarf grizzly''', and '''North American sun bear''') is a variety of [[American black bear]] (''Ursus americanus'') found in the lava beds of south central [[Oregon]]. The animal was described as a very small bear with wooly light brown fur. The few lava bears that were killed or captured were a little larger than a [[badger]]. It was once thought to be a separate species. However, scientists who examined the specimens determined that the animals were stunted due to the harsh environment in which they lived. Today, it is acknowledged that lava bears never existed as a unique species.
== Description ==
When lava bears were first encountered in the early [[20th century]] it was speculated that they might be a unique species, possibly a dwarf [[Grizzly bear|grizzly]]. The diminutive bears resembled [[American black bear|black bear]]s in many ways, but were much smaller with wooly fur that was light brown in color, similar to [[grizzly bear]]s. Specimens taken by hunters were a little larger than a badger. They were approximately {{convert|17|in|cm}} to {{convert|30|in|cm}} long and between {{convert|12|in|cm}} and {{convert|18|in|cm}} high. The bears weighed between {{convert|23|lb|kg}} and {{convert|35|lb|kg}}. Gray hair on their muzzles along with well-worn claws and teeth indicated that some of the specimens were adult bears.<ref name="GMI">Ingram, Guy M., [https://archive.org/stream/oregonsportsman05port#page/275/mode/2up "The Little Bear Wonder of Oregon"], ''The Oregon Sportsman'' (Volume 5, Issue 4), Oregon State Sportsmen's League, Portland, Oregon, October 1917, pp. 275–276</ref><ref name="SGJ">Jewett, Stanley G., [https://archive.org/details/jstor-3533662 "The So-Called Dwarf Bear of Oregon"], ''The Murrelet'' (Volume 3), Pacific Northwest Bird and Mammal Society, Seattle, Washington, 1 October 1922, p. 9.</ref><ref name="RRH">Hatton, Raymond R., ''Pioneer Homesteaders of the Fort Rock Valley'', Binford and Mort, Portland, Oregon, 1982, pp. 76–78.</ref><ref name="LAK">Kriegh, LeeAnn, "Lava Bear", ''The Nature of Bend'', Tempo Press, Bend, Oregon, 2016, p. 211.</ref><ref name="ERG">[https://news.google.com/newspapers?nid=1310&dat=19340719&id=qrJWAAAAIBAJ&sjid=WOgDAAAAIBAJ&pg=1443,2509111&hl=en "Lave Bear Shown at McKenzie Bridge"], ''Eugene Reigister-Guard'', Eugene, Oregon, 19 July 1934, p. 1.</ref>
One of the first lava bear specimens taken in the wild was mounted and sent to [[United States Fish and Wildlife Service|United States Bureau of Biological Survey]] in [[Washington, District of Columbia|Washington]], [[District of Columbia]]. Eventually, scientist determined that lava bears were American black bears (''Ursus americanus''), stunted by malnutrition caused by the austere environment where the animals lived and foraged.<ref name="SGJ"/><ref name="LAK"/><ref>Finley, William L., [http://oregonnews.uoregon.edu/lccn/sn83025138/1921-01-14/ed-1/seq-10/#index=0&rows=20&words=bear+BEAR+bears+LAVA+lava&sequence=0&proxtext=%22Lava+bear%22&y=20&x=14&dateFilterType=range&page=1 "Proof Lacking for Lava Bear"], ''Morning Oregonian'', Portland, Oregon, 14 January 1921, p. 10.</ref><ref name="DHM">[http://www.deschuteshistory.org/about-us/faq "Frequently Asked Questions"], Des Chutes Historical Museum, Deschutes County Historical Society, Bend, Oregon, accessed 1 August 2016.</ref>
== History ==
From 1917 through the early 1930s, a number of people reported seeing small bears in the lava beds and surrounding [[High desert (Oregon)|high desert]] county of northern [[Lake County, Oregon]]. The bears were initially called ''sand lappers'', but eventually became known as lava bears. The first documented encounter was in 1917, when a sheepherder name O. T. McKendree killed a small bear near [[Fossil Lake (Oregon)|Fossil Lake]]. Originally, McKendree thought it was a black bear cub, but upon further inspection he found the animal was a very small adult bear. He had the animal mounted by a [[taxidermist]]. The mounted lava bear was exhibited in [[The Dalles, Oregon|The Dalles]] and later in [[Lakeview, Oregon|Lakeview]].<ref name="GMI"/><ref name="SGJ"/><ref name="ADD">[https://www.newspapers.com/image/111193548/?terms=%22Lava%2BBear%22 "Lava bears"], ''Albany Daily Democrat'', Albany, Oregon, 17 June 1923, p. 4.{{subscription}}</ref> A photograph of the mounted bear was published in ''Oregon Sportsman'' magazine in October 1917.<ref name="GMI"/> Eventually, the mounted specimen was sent to Washington, D. C., where it was examined by [[Clinton Hart Merriam]] of the Bureau of Biological Survey. Merriam, an expert on North American bears, determined that the specimen was an unusually small American black bear.<ref name="SGJ"/>
Publicity generated by the ''Oregon Sportsman'' photograph and various newspaper articles about the miniature bear made it a fascinating creature. In 1920, [[Irvin S. Cobb]], a well-known writer for ''[[The Saturday Evening Post]]'', organized a hunting trip to Oregon with the stated purpose of finding a lava bear.<ref name="LAK"/><ref name="PFB">Brogan, Phil F., [http://ir.library.oregonstate.edu/xmlui/bitstream/handle/1957/12696/VisitorInformationDeschutesNationalForest.pdf "Deschutes Recreation Forest"], ''Visitor Information Service Book for the Deschutes National Forest'', Deschutes National Forest, United States Forest Service, Bend, Oregon, 1969, p. 126.</ref><ref name="MO1">[http://oregonnews.uoregon.edu/lccn/sn83025138/1920-09-14/ed-1/seq-1/#index=5&rows=20&words=bear+lava&sequence=0&proxtext=%22Lava+bear%22&y=20&x=14&dateFilterType=range&page=1 "Cobb Discovers Sun Bear Yet in Oregon"], ''Morning Oregonian'', Portland, Oregon, 14 September 1920, p. 1.</ref> While Cobb did not locate a lava bear during his hunt, he left Oregon believing they existed. He thought the little bears were a dwarf grizzly or a species of [[sun bear]], unique to North America. After he left Oregon, several of the local trappers who accompanied Cobb began to actively search for lava bears. In addition, the story Cobb wrote about his hunting trip for ''The Saturday Evening Post'' increased interest in the animal across the county.<ref name="MO1"/><ref>[https://www.newspapers.com/image/96035029/?terms=%22Lava%2BBear%22 "Lava Bear May Be Scientific Find, Believed"], ''Bend Bulletin'', Bend, Oregon, 13 September 1920, p. 1.</ref><ref name="ISC">Cobb, Irvin S., [https://books.google.com/books?id=4F4wAQAAMAAJ&pg=PP21&lpg "A Quest in Youbetcherland"], ''The Saturday Evening Post'' (Volume 193, Issue 3), 1 January 1921, p. 6-7, 49–50, 52 & 54.</ref>
In 1923, Alfred Andrews, a trapper for the [[United States Forest Service]], reported killing a lava bear near [[Fort Rock]]. He sent the specimen to the Oregon biological survey office for examination.<ref name="ADD"/><ref>[https://www.newspapers.com/image/96034882/?terms=%22Lava%2BBear%22 "Bagged Lava Bear Belief of Hunter"], ''Bend Bulletin'', Bend, Oregon, 9 June 1923, p. 8.{{subscription}}</ref><ref name="BB1">[https://www.newspapers.com/image/94790782/?terms=%22Lava%2BBear%22%2B%22Alfred%2BAndrews%22 "The Lava Bear Trapper"], ''Bend Bulletin'', Bend, Oregon, 4 March 1937, p. 4.{{subscription}}</ref> A year later, Andrews captured a live lava bear. The animal looked like a small grizzly bear, but weighed only {{convert|28|lb|kg}}. It was a male, {{convert|30|in|cm}} long and {{convert|18|in|cm}} high. The [[Smithsonian]] offered Andrews $2,000 for the live lava bear, but he decided not to sell the animal. Instead, he announced plans to tour the country with the bear.<ref name="LAK"/><ref name="PFB"/><ref name="BB1"/><ref>[https://www.newspapers.com/image/94799009/?terms=%22Lava%2BBear%22 "Lava Bear is Caught Alive"], ''Bend Bulletin'', Bend, Oregon, 16 May 1924, p. 1.{{subscription}}</ref><ref>[https://news.google.com/newspapers?nid=1314&dat=19240704&id=351XAAAAIBAJ&sjid=s_MDAAAAIBAJ&pg=6343,149141&hl=en "Nabs Lava Bear Near Fort Rock"], ''Spokesman-Review'', Spokane, Washington, 4 July 1924, p. 10.</ref> He displayed the bear in Portland, where 8,000 people paid to see the animal.<ref name="RRH"/><ref name="LAK"/><ref name="BB1"/><ref>[https://www.newspapers.com/image/94799232/?terms=%22Lava%2BBear%22 "Lava Bear Shown to Portland Folks"], ''Bend Bulletin'', Bend, Oregon, 25 June 1924, p. 6.{{subscription}}</ref> It was also exhibited in [[Bend, Oregon|Bend]] and [[Klamath Falls, Oregon|Klamath Falls]] before being taken to [[Los Angeles, California|Los Angeles]], [[California]]. Eventually, Andrews' partner Harry Thrall stole or sold the bear and the animal disappeared.<ref name="RRH"/><ref>[https://www.newspapers.com/image/96369545/?terms=%22Lava%2BBear%22 "Caged Life Liked by Dwarf Grizzly"], ''Bend Bulletin'', Bend, Oregon, 16 October 1924, p. 6.{{subscription}}</ref>
In the fall of 1924, a second lava bear was captured alive near [[Summer Lake (Oregon)|Summer Lake]]. That bear weighed only {{convert|25|lb|kg}}.<ref>[https://www.newspapers.com/image/96370512/?terms=%22Lava%2BBear%22 "Second Lava Bear is Taken in Lake"], ''Bend Bulletin'', Bend, Oregon, 10 November 1924, p. 1.{{subscription}}</ref> Another lava bear was trapped by L. E. Oster in the lava beds northeast of Fort Rock in 1933.<ref name="RRH"/><ref>[https://www.newspapers.com/image/96330790/?terms=%22Lava%2BBear%22 "Lava Bear is Not Too Tame"], ''Bend Bulletin'', Bend, Oregon, 23 November 1933, p. 1.{{subscription}}</ref> A fourth lava bear was taken alive the following year by Walter Gore and Roy Yeager in an area east of [[Crescent Lake (Oregon)|Crescent Lake]]. It weighed {{convert|30|lb|kg}} and resembled a miniature grizzly.<ref>[https://www.newspapers.com/image/96331122 "Another Lava Bear Reported"], ''Bend Bulletin'', Bend, Oregon, 20 January 1934, p. 1.{{subscription}}</ref><ref>[https://www.newspapers.com/image/152536816/?terms=%22Lava%2BBear%22 "Rare Lave Bear is Exhibited by Lapine Trappers"], ''Eugene Register-Guard'', Eugene, Oregon, 20 January 1934, p. 1.{{subscription}}</ref> The last animal identified as a lava bear was captured in 1934 by a forest road crew near Scar Mountain in the [[Willamette National Forest]]. It was {{convert|17|in|cm}} long and weighed {{convert|25|lb|kg}}. It was exhibited for a time in [[McKenzie Bridge, Oregon]] before the animal was sold to a man named Alfred Bayne.<ref name="ERG"/> As late as 1981, scientist were being asked to identify small bear tracks in the Fort Rock area to determine if they were made by lava bears.<ref name="RRH"/>
Today, it is accepted that lava bears are actually common American black bears. It is also generally acknowledged that all of the animals that were killed or captured between 1917 and 1934 were either black bear cubs or small adults stunted from malnutrition.<ref name="DHM"/><ref name="PFB"/>
== Popular culture ==
In 1924, [[Bend Senior High School]] selected the lava bear as the school’s sports mascot. The mascot was chosen shortly after a living bear was exhibited in Bend. At the time, it was thought that lava bears might be a species unique to Central Oregon.<ref name="RRH"/><ref>[https://www.newspapers.com/image/94799705/?terms=%22Lava%2BBear%22 "Bend Eleven in Christened"], ''Bend Bulletin'', Bend, Oregon,16 September 1924, p. 3.{{subscription}}</ref> In 2013, ''[[The Oregonian]]'' newspaper conducted a statewide survey, asking Oregon sports fans to identify their favorite high school team mascots. Fans from across the state of Oregon, selected Bend’s ''Lava Bear'' as their top pick for large school mascot.<ref>Beyrle, Jen, [http://highschoolsports.oregonlive.com/news/article/-6407406660419497156/bend-lava-bears-voted-best-mascot-in-oregon-for-class-5a "Bend Lava Bears voted best mascot in Oregon for Class 5A"], ''OregonLive/The Oregonian'', Portland, Oregon, 19 September 2013.</ref>
== References == {{reflist|colwidth=30em}}
== External links == *[https://books.google.com/books?id=4F4wAQAAMAAJ&pg=PP21&lpg ''The Saturday Evening Post'' article by Irvin S. Cobb about his 1920 lava bear hunt] *[http://www.deschuteshistory.org/about-us/faq Des Chutes Historical Museum frequently asked questions: Are there such things as Lava Bears?]

{{more footnotes|date=June 2010}} {{US Income}} The following is a list of the '''highest-income urban areas in the United States'''. The [[U.S. Census Bureau]] defines two types of [[United States urban area|urban area]]s. They are listed below, along with their Census definitions. * '''Urbanized Area (UA)''', ''an area consisting of a central place(s) and adjacent territory with a general population density of at least 1,000 people per square mile of land area that together have a minimum residential population of at least 50,000 people. The Census Bureau uses published criteria to determine the qualification and boundaries of UAs.'' * '''Urban Cluster (UC)''', ''a densely settled territory that has at least 2,500 people but fewer than 50,000.'' == Urban areas ranked by per capita income == === Urban areas of any population === {| class="toccolours sortable" clear="both" align="center" cellpadding="4" cellspacing="3" style="border: 1px solid #707070;" |- style="background:#efefef;" ! {{Infobox rail line | box_width = | name = Marmifera | color = | logo = | logo_width = | image = Carrara ponti di Vara01 2007-03-30.jpg | image_width = 270px | caption = Viaduct of Vara | type = | system = | status = Suppressed | locale = [[Carrara]] ([[Italy]]) | start = [[Colonnata]] | end = [[Marina di Carrara]] | stations = 17 | routes = | daily_ridership = | open = 1876 | close = 1964 | reopen = | owner = Società Ferrovia Marmifera Privata di Carrara | operator = [[Società per le strade ferrate dell'Alta Italia|SFAI]] | character = | depot = | stock = ? | linelength = {{convert|16.50|km|mi|abbr=on}} | tracklength = | tracks = [[Single track (rail)|Single track]] | gauge = {{RailGauge|1435mm|lk=on}} | minradius = | electrification = | maxincline = | racksystem = | speed = | elevation = | map = | map_state = }} [[File:Carrara, Ferrovia Marmifera - Ponte di Ferro.JPG|thumb|right|230px|The iron gate at Caina, near Carrara Monterosso station]] [[File:Ferrovia Marmifera Carrara -1890.jpg|thumb|right|230px|Front page of ''L'eco del Carrione'' (1890) announcing the inauguration of the entire line]] The '''Marmifera''', full name {{lang-it|'''Ferrovia Marmifera Privata di Carrara'''|italic=no|lit=private marble railway of Carrara}}, was an [[Italy|Italian]] [[industrial railway]] used for the transport of [[Carrara marble]] from the [[Quarry|quarries]] of the municipal territory of [[Carrara]], [[Tuscany]]. The route extended from the hillside village of [[Colonnata]] to the port of [[Marina di Carrara]].{{it icon}} [http://www.ferroviamarmifera.com/ Infos on the Marmifera di Carrara website] == History == The railway, projected in 1866, was inaugurated in 1876 and was connected to the pre-existent [[Avenza-Carrara railway]] (1866),{{it icon}} [http://www.ferrovieabbandonate.it/linea_dismessa.php?table=dismessa&type=search&r=Toscana&g=Ferrovie%20dello%20Stato&s=Ordinario&l=Avenza&id=14&start=0 Avenza-Carrara railway on ferrovieabbandonate.it (site about abandoned railways)] linking the main station of [[Carrara-Avenza railway station|Carrara Avenza]] to [[Carrara San Martino railway station|Carrara San Martino]], in city centre.{{it icon}} [http://www.ferroviamarmifera.com/lastoria01.htm History of Marmifera di Carrara (part 2)] A subsequent expansion to the quarries below the [[Apuan Alps]] (Gioia, Ravaccione-Polvaccio and [[Colonnata]]) was proposed in 1885. Work began in 1887 and the new branch was inaugurated on 15 May 1890.{{it icon}} [http://www.ferroviamarmifera.com/lastoria02.htm History of Marmifera di Carrara (part 3)]{{it icon}} [http://www.carraraonline.com/la_marmifera.php The "Marmifera" railway on "Carrara Online"] The line was owned by the SFMPC (Società Ferrovia Marmifera Privata di Carrara) and operated by the SFAI ([[Società per le strade ferrate dell'Alta Italia]]).{{it icon}} [http://www.comune.carrara.ms.it/sezioni.aspx?id=1285 Article about the Marmifera and SFMPC on Carrara official municipal website] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140222031458/http://www.comune.carrara.ms.it/sezioni.aspx?id=1285 |date=2014-02-22 }} Even if its bridges were damaged by bombings and sabotages during the [[Second World War]], the line was practically in continuous operation from 1876 to 1964, when it was closed due to competition from road traffic. In 1969 it was closed also the passenger route Avenza-Carrara and the [[Track (rail transport)|rail tracks]] dismantled.{{it icon}} [http://www.ferroviamarmifera.com/lastoria04.htm History of Marmifera di Carrara (part 5)] Nowadays, apart Avenza FS station, the only area in which the railway is operating is the [[port of Carrara]], connected to the [[Pisa–La Spezia–Genoa railway|Pisa-La Spezia-Genoa line]] with a pair of industrial lines. It is part of a route of [[industrial archaeology]] and, since 2003 its stations, quarries and bridges over the [[Vara (river)|Vara]], have been included in the Archaeological Park of the [[Apuan Alps]].{{it icon}} [http://www.archeominerario.it/documenti/elenco_siti_beni_parco.PDF List of possible heritage sites in the Apuan Alps National Park (see page 3, section 7)] == Route == The railway line started in the hill village of [[Colonnata]] and, following a tortuous path, connects some hill hamlets of Carrara, as [[Miseglia]] and [[Torano, Carrara|Torano]], and several quarries, through some branches. Subsequently the railway runs through the city of Carrara and, from San Martino to Avenza station follows a path almost parallel to that of the passenger line. From Avenza FS station to the port, in [[Marina di Carrara]], the line follows a straight parallel to that of [[Carrara-Marina di Carrara Tramway|the former tramway]], with a small branch to the station of Covetta.[http://www.ferroviamarmifera.com/Immagini/lamarmifera013.JPG Map of Marmifera railway][[:commons:File:Tram Carrara.JPG|Map of Carrara Tramway]] The only stations passenger service was the one from Avenza to San Martino stations."General Timetable of Italian Railways", July 1933. Éditions du Cabri, 1984. {{ISBN|2-903310-39-4}}. {| class="wikitable sortable" !width="130px| Station !width="30px| Km !width="300px| Notes |- |'''Colonnata''' |
