revision.text:
'''Pakistanism''', or '''Pakistanisation''',{{cite book |title=Nyerere and Africa: End of an Era |first=Godfrey |last=Mwakikagile |authorlink=Godfrey Mwakikagile |year=2010 |publisher=New Africa Press |location=Pretoria, South Africa, Dar es Salaam, Tanzania |isbn=0-9802534-1-1 |page=50 |pages= |edition=5th |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=D4LcR4iOmcYC&pg=PA50 |accessdate=2011-09-02}} is a [[neologism]] that refers to the continual division of any society along religious lines.{{citation needed|date=August 2012}} Some West Africans were inspired by the [[Indian independence movement]].{{cite book |title=Political Values and the Educated Class in Africa |first=Ali Al'Amin |last=Mazrui |authorlink=Ali Mazrui |year=1978 |publisher=University of California Press |location=Berkeley and Los Angeles |isbn=0-520-03292-6 |page=104 |pages= |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=IA8F6eKRVysC&pg=PA104 |accessdate=2011-08-31}} In 1920, educated West Africans formed the [[National Congress of British West Africa]], which modeled its name on the [[Indian National Congress]].{{cite book |title=Decolonization: The Fall of the European Empires |first=Muriel Evelyn |last=Chamberlain |authorlink= |year=1999 |publisher=Blackwell Publishing |location=Oxford |isbn=0-631-21602-2 |page=11 |pages= |edition=2nd |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=YYMwBRvtb1UC&pg=PA11 |accessdate=2011-09-27}} According to [[Ali Mazrui]], the facet of the Indian independence movement West Africans found most admirable was the Indian peoples' unity during the struggle. In 1936, [[H. O. Davies]] said,
"Africans should follow India – the only way is for Africans to co-operate and make sacrifices in the struggle for freedom."
According to Ali Mazrui,
"But the emergence of the Muslim League in India as a serious secessionist movement soon shattered the myth of unity in the Indian model. A new word entered the vocabulary of West African nationalism – the word was 'pakistanism'."
[[Ghana]]'s [[Kwame Nkrumah]] and [[Nigeria]]'s [[Nnamdi Azikiwe]] became concerned about possible Pakistanization.{{cite book |title=Zik: a selection from the speeches of Nnamdi Azikiwe |first=Nnamdi |last=Azikiwe |authorlink=Nnamdi Azikiwe |year=1961 |publisher=Cambridge University Press|location=London |isbn= |page=173 |pages= |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=Iec7AAAAIAAJ&pg=PA173 |accessdate=2011-09-01}} The [[Convention People's Party]]'s 1954 Election Manifesto contain the following message:
"We have seen the tragedy of religious communalism in India and elsewhere. Don't let us give it a chance to take root and flourish in Ghana. Down with Pakistanism!"{{cite book |title=Political Values and the Educated Class in Africa |first=Ali Al'Amin |last=Mazrui |authorlink=Ali Mazrui |year=1978 |publisher=University of California Press |location=Berkeley and Los Angeles |isbn=0-520-03292-6 |page=105 |pages= |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=IA8F6eKRVysC&pg=PA105 |accessdate=2011-09-02}}
Pakistanism became a concern in [[Nigeria]]'s independence movement. The primary subdivisions of Nigeria consisted of the [[Hausa-Fulani]]-dominated [[Northern Region, Nigeria|Northern Region]], the [[Yoruba people|Yoruba]]-dominated [[Western Region, Nigeria|Western Region]], and the [[Igbo people|Igbo]]-dominated [[Eastern Region, Nigeria|Eastern Region]]. In addition to these ethnic differences, the Northern Region was primarily [[Muslim]], while the Western and Eastern regions were primarily [[Christian]]. In the 1950s, the Northern Region threatened to secede. [[Godfrey Mwakikagile]] noted that it was the Northern region that was the first region threatening to secede.{{cite book |title=Ethnic Politics in Kenya and Nigeria |first=Godfrey |last=Mwakikagile |authorlink=Godfrey Mwakikagile |year=2001 |publisher=[[Nova Science Publishers, Inc.]] |location=Huntington, NY |isbn=1-56072-967-8 |page=4 |pages= |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=gqTjUjdvTQwC&pg=PA4 |accessdate=2011-09-02}} At the 1950 General Conference at Ibadan, Northern Region delegates demanded 50% of the seat in Nigeria's legislature, and they threatened to secede if this demand was not met. In 1958, Nnamdi Azikiwe said,
"It is essential that ill-will be not created in order to encourage a Pakistan in this country."
The original goal of the counter-coup against the government of [[Johnson Aguiyi-Ironsi]] on July 29, 1966, was to facilitate the Northern Region's secession from the rest of Nigeria.{{cite book |title=Oil, democracy, and the Promise of true Federalism in Nigeria |first1=Augustine A. |last1=Ikein |first2=Diepreye S. P. |last2=Alamieyeseigha |first3=Steve S. |last3=Azaiki |year=2008 |publisher=University Press of America |location=Lanham, Maryland |isbn=0-7618-3928-3 |page=363 |pages= |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=qzL0-nBbMCQC&pg=PA363 |accessdate=2011-09-26}} In February 2011, Ali Mazrui used the term to describe the division of the [[Sudan]] into Sudan proper, which is primarily Muslim, and [[South Sudan]], which is primarily Christian and [[animism|animistic]].{{cite web |url=https://www.theguardian.com/commentisfree/2011/feb/09/sudan-secession-postcolonial-africa |title=Is this Pakistanism in Sudan? |first=Ali |last=Mazrui |authorlink=Ali Mazrui |date=2011-02-09 |work=guardian.co.uk |publisher= |accessdate=2011-08-31}} ==See also== {{Portal|Pakistan|Africa|Religion|Politics}} *[[Two-nation theory]] *[[Balkanization]] ==References== {{Reflist}} [[Category:Africa–Pakistan relations]] [[Category:Political terminology in Pakistan]] [[Category:Pakistan studies]] [[Category:Political neologisms]] [[Category:Religion and society]] [[Category:Pakistani social culture]]

'''Pointy ears''' or '''pointed ears''' are a characteristic of numerous animals, at least one genetic disorder in humans, as well as a popular [[cliché]] in [[popular culture]], particularly in the [[fantasy]] [[genre]].
==Animals== [[File:Southern Bush Pig.jpg|thumbnail|A Southern Bush Pig]] Pointy ears is a characteristic of some animals, for example the [[cat]], the [[vampire bats]],<ref name="Gerholdt1996">{{cite book|author=Pamela J. Gerholdt|title=Vampire Bats|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=PxO0xc7fMm0C&pg=PA12|year=1996|publisher=ABDO|isbn=978-1-56239-505-6|page=12}}</ref> [[civets]] and [[Genet (animal)|genets]] of the [[viverridae]] family,<ref name="Merritt2010">{{cite book|author=Joseph F. Merritt|title=The Biology of Small Mammals|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=LF_x_kmDjr4C&pg=PA129|date=4 February 2010|publisher=JHU Press|isbn=978-0-8018-7950-0|pages=128–129}}</ref> [[red panda]]s<ref>{{cite book|title=Concise Encyclopedia Biology|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=FCXd7VEsdPcC&pg=PA1015|date=1 January 1996|publisher=Walter de Gruyter|isbn=978-3-11-088956-7|page=1015}}</ref> and [[African bush pig]]s.<ref>{{cite book|title=Concise Encyclopedia Biology|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=FCXd7VEsdPcC&pg=PA22|date=1 January 1996|publisher=Walter de Gruyter|isbn=978-3-11-088956-7|page=22}}</ref>
==Humans== One of the characteristics of the [[Williams syndrome]] has been described as "pointed ears".<ref name="JohnsonMunakata2008">{{cite book|author1=Mark H. Johnson|author2=Yuko Munakata|author3=Rick O. Gilmore|title=Brain Development and Cognition: A Reader|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=1e_h9G4z5QcC&pg=PA384|date=15 April 2008|publisher=John Wiley & Sons|isbn=978-0-470-75202-9|page=384}}</ref><ref name="Magazine2008">{{cite book|author=Scientific American|title=What Makes a Genius?|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=PrHEeyNQxZEC&pg=PA37|date=1 January 2008|publisher=The Rosen Publishing Group|isbn=978-1-4042-1401-9|page=37}}</ref> There are also cases of people being born with pointed ears not associated to William's syndrome. In one family a woman was born with two pointed ears, she later had a son with two less dramatically pointed ears, and she had a great uncle with one pointed ear. Some cases of pointed ears may be due to trauma to ears during labor, and the ear crease may unfold with time.
==Folklore and fiction== [[File:Elvish-archer.svg|thumbnail|Anime-style elvish archer with pointed ears]] [[File:Chara05.png|thumbnail|Manga and anime-style character with pointed ears]] Pointy ears have been a characteristic of some creatures in [[folklore]] such as French [[croquemitaine]], Brazilian [[curupira]]<ref name="Bane2013">{{cite book|author=Theresa Bane|title=Encyclopedia of Fairies in World Folklore and Mythology|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=rUqpAAAAQBAJ&pg=PA91|date=4 September 2013|publisher=McFarland|isbn=978-0-7864-7111-9|page=91}}</ref> or Japanese [[earth spider]].<ref name="Bush2001">{{cite book|author=Laurence Bush|title=Asian Horror Encyclopedia: Asian Horror Culture in Literature, Manga, and Folklore|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=JvYV8EmdejMC&pg=PA43|date=5 October 2001|publisher=iUniverse|isbn=978-1-4697-1503-2|page=43}}</ref> It has been a feature of characters on art as old as that of [[Ancient Greece]]<ref name="Winckelmann1850">{{cite book|author=Johann Joachim Winckelmann|title=The History of Ancient Art Among the Greeks|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=zHwEAAAAYAAJ&pg=PA80|year=1850|publisher=Chapman|page=80}}</ref> and [[medieval Europe]].<ref name="Bovey2002">{{cite book|author=Alixe Bovey|title=Monsters and Grotesques in Medieval Manuscripts|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=8rytlDZ4xdgC&pg=PA38|year=2002|publisher=University of Toronto Press|isbn=978-0-8020-8512-2|page=38}}</ref>
Pointy ears are common characteristic of many creatures in the [[fantasy]] genre.<ref name="Peffer2012">{{cite book|author=J. Peffer|title=DragonArt Collector's Edition: Your Ultimate Guide to Drawing Fantasy Art|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=jcPqm5smoMMC&pg=PA28|date=25 October 2012|publisher=IMPACT|isbn=1-4403-2417-4|page=28}}</ref> It's a common characteristics of races such as, among others, [[elves]],<ref name="Tresca2010">{{cite book|author=Michael J. Tresca|title=The Evolution of Fantasy Role-Playing Games|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=8H8bzqj6S4sC&pg=PA34|date=16 November 2010|publisher=McFarland|isbn=978-0-7864-6009-0|page=34}}</ref><ref name="Okum2006"/><ref name="Knight2005"/> [[faeries]],<ref name="Greer2011">{{cite book|author=John Michael Greer|title=Monsters|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=qDda4Q27kXYC&pg=PT107|date=1 September 2011|publisher=Llewellyn Worldwide|isbn=978-0-7387-1600-8|page=107}}</ref><ref name="Hart2008">{{cite book|author=Christopher Hart|title=Astonishing Fantasy Worlds: The Ultimate Guide to Drawing Adventure Fantasy Art|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=geE2AQAAIAAJ|year=2008|publisher=Watson-Guptill Publications|isbn=978-0-8230-1472-9|page=103}}</ref> [[pixie]]s,<ref name="Hamilton2011">{{cite book|author=John Hamilton|title=Elves and Fairies|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=glzvoVQwqwoC&pg=PA23|date=1 August 2011|publisher=ABDO|isbn=978-1-60453-215-9|page=23}}</ref> [[hobbit]]s,<ref name="KavkaLawn2006">{{cite book|author1=Misha Kavka|author2=Jenny Lawn|author3=Mary Paul|title=Gothic Nz: The Darker Side of Kiwi Culture|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=pshlAAAAMAAJ|year=2006|publisher=Otago University Press|isbn=978-1-877372-23-0|page=111}}</ref> or [[orcs]].<ref name="Hopkins2010">{{cite book|author=Lisa Hopkins|title=Screening the Gothic|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=4dmGAAAAQBAJ&pg=PT202|date=1 January 2010|publisher=University of Texas Press|isbn=978-0-292-77959-4|page=202}}</ref> They are also a characteristic of creatures from the [[horror literature|horror]] genre, such as [[vampire]]s.<ref name="Isenberg2013">{{cite book|author=Noah William Isenberg|title=Weimar Cinema: An Essential Guide to Classic Films of the Era|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=A9vbWimrmcEC&pg=PT96|date=13 August 2013|publisher=Columbia University Press|isbn=978-0-231-50385-3|pages=96–}}</ref><ref name="Gelder2000">{{cite book|author=Ken Gelder|title=The Horror Reader|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=upGM6haNBR8C&pg=PA27|year=2000|publisher=Psychology Press|isbn=978-0-415-21356-1|page=27}}</ref>
This characteristic has been adopted into the Japanese [[anime]] and [[manga]] art style, where pointy ears are also a common trope of fantasy characters.<ref name="Studio2007">{{cite book|author=Ikari Studio|title=The Monster Book of More Manga|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=5tA2AQAAIAAJ|date=28 March 2007|publisher=HarperCollins|isbn=978-0-06-115169-9|page=19}}</ref><ref name="SouthgateSparrow2011">{{cite book|author1=Anna Southgate|author2=Keith Sparrow|title=Drawing Manga Expressions and Poses|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=iFA6g0BOjIcC&pg=PA17|date=August 2011|publisher=The Rosen Publishing Group|isbn=978-1-4488-4800-3|page=17}}</ref> Manga and anime elves in particular are distinguished by very prominently displayed pointed ears, often drawn larger and more distinctly visible, as well as more angled, than in the Western works.<ref name="Okum2006">{{cite book|author=David Okum|title=Manga Fantasy Madness: Over 50 Basic Lessons for Drawing Warriors, Wizards, Monsters and more|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=_4aPjotgxJcC&pg=PA31|date=21 April 2006|publisher=IMPACT|isbn=1-60061-381-0|page=31}}</ref><ref name="Okum2005">{{cite book|author=David Okum|title=Manga Monster Madness|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=Ga3y7Dms2w0C&pg=PA34|date=15 March 2005|publisher=IMPACT|isbn=1-60061-387-X|page=34}}</ref>
Pointy ears have become associated with elves in [[Victorian literature]] of the 19th century.<ref name="Knight2005">{{cite book|author=Sirona Knight|title=The Complete Idiot's Guide to Elves and Fairies|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=7m5s8HmpSp8C&pg=PT171|date=7 June 2005|publisher=DK Publishing|isbn=978-1-4406-9638-1|page=171}}</ref> Popularization of the pointed ears as an attribute of elves has been attributed to the works of [[J. R. R. Tolkien]] and their more recent big screen interpretation, though the status of elvish ears as [[Canon (fiction)|canon]] is not universally accepted by the [[Tolkien fandom]].<ref name="Tresca2010"/><ref>{{cite web|url=http://middle-earth.xenite.org/2011/09/21/do-tolkiens-elves-have-pointy-ears/ |title=Do Tolkien’s Elves Have Pointy Ears? | Middle-earth & J.R.R. Tolkien Blog by Michael Martinez |publisher=Middle-earth.xenite.org |date=2011-09-21 |accessdate=2014-04-18}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|author=F.A.Q. |url=http://www.tolkiensociety.org/the-author/faq/#ears |title=F.A.Q. |publisher=The Tolkien Society |date= |accessdate=2014-04-18}}</ref><ref name="BogstadKaveny2011">{{cite book|author1=Janice M. Bogstad|author2=Philip E. Kaveny|title=Picturing Tolkien: Essays on Peter Jackson's The Lord of the Rings Film Trilogy|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=jNjKrXRP0G8C&pg=PA86|date=9 August 2011|publisher=McFarland|isbn=978-0-7864-8473-7|page=86}}</ref>
Pointy ears are also found in the [[science fiction]] genre; for example among the [[Vulcan (Star Trek)|Vulcan]] and [[Romulan]] races of the [[Star Trek]] universe<ref name="IIIMcPherson2003">{{cite book|author1=Henry Jenkins III|author2=Tara McPherson|author3=Jane Shattuc|title=Hop on Pop: The Politics and Pleasures of Popular Culture|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=ZZSz3ThOv9gC&pg=PA119|date=2 January 2003|publisher=Duke University Press|isbn=0-8223-8350-0|page=119}}</ref> or the [[Nightcrawler (comics)|Nightcrawler]] character from the [[X-Men]] universe.<ref name="IrwinHousel2009">{{cite book|author1=William Irwin|author2=Rebecca Housel|author3=J. Jeremy Wisnewski|title=X-Men and Philosophy: Astonishing Insight and Uncanny Argument in the Mutant X-Verse|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=bK-ax5Ttj3wC&pg=PA189|date=18 May 2009|publisher=John Wiley & Sons|isbn=978-0-470-73036-2|page=189}}</ref>

{{About|the person who controls a puppet|puppet master|Puppet Master (disambiguation){{!}}Puppet Master|other uses|Puppeteer (disambiguation)}} [[File:Nikolai Zykov with hand puppets, Russia.jpg|thumb|Puppeteer with hand puppets.]] A '''puppeteer''' is a person who manipulates an inanimate object that might be shaped like a human, animal or mythical creature, or another object to create the illusion that the [[puppet]] is "alive". The puppeteer may be visible to or hidden from the audience. A puppeteer can operate a puppet indirectly by the use of strings, rods, wires, electronics or directly by his or her own hands placed inside the puppet or holding it externally or any other part of the body- such as the legs. Some puppet styles require two or more puppeteers to work together to create a single puppet character.
The puppeteer's role is to manipulate the physical object in such a manner that the audience believes the object is imbued with life. In some instances, the persona of the puppeteer is also an important feature, as with [[ventriloquist's dummy]] performers, in which the puppeteer and the human figure-styled puppet appear onstage together, and in theatre shows like ''[[Avenue Q]]''.
The puppeteer might speak in the role of the puppet's character, synchronising the movements of the puppet's "mouth". However, there is much puppetry which does not use the moving mouth (which is a lip-sync innovation created originally for television where close-up "headshots" are popular). Often, in theatre, a moveable mouth is used only for gestural expression, or speech might be produced by a non-moving mouth. In traditional glove puppetry often one puppeteer will operate two puppets at a time out of a cast of several. Much work is produced without any speech at all with all the emphasis on movement
The relationship between the puppeteer and the puppet-maker is similar to that between an [[actor]] and a [[playwright]], in cases where a puppet-maker designs a puppet for a puppeteer. Very often, though, the puppeteer assumes the joint roles of puppet-maker, [[Theatre director|director]], [[designer]], writer and [[performer]]. In this case a puppeteer is a more complete theatre practitioner than is the case with other theatre forms, in which one person writes a play, another person directs it, and then [[actor]]s perform the lines and gestures.
Puppetry is a complex medium sometimes consisting of live performance, sometimes contributing to stop frame puppet animation, and film where performances might be technically processed as motion capture, CGI or as virtual puppetry.

[[Ernie (Sesame Street)|Ernie]], [[Guy Smiley]], and several others from ''[[Sesame Street]]''. Convincing John and Cantus the Minstrel from ''[[Fraggle Rock]]''. Jim Henson is one of the best known of modern recent puppeteers who with his associates [[Jerry Juhl]] and [[Frank Oz]] developed [[The Muppets]] for television. Jim Henson's work has entertained children for decades on television series such as ''[[Sesame Street]]'' and the adult oriented ''[[The Muppet Show]]''. * [[John Henson (puppeteer)|John Henson]] (1965 - 2014) - He was trained by Richard Hunt to perform [[List of Muppets#Sweetums|Sweetums]]. Also performed Placido Flamingo, Gladys the Cow, Sully, Don Music, the [[Two-Headed Monster]], and several others from ''[[Sesame Street]]'', as well as Junior Gorg and others from ''[[Fraggle Rock]]''. * [[Max Jacob]] - Founder of the Hohnsteiner Kasper Theatre in Germany in the 1920s. * [[Eric Jacobson]] - [[Miss Piggy]], [[Fozzie Bear]], [[Dr. Teeth and The Electric Mayhem#Animal|Animal]], and [[Sam Eagle|Sam the Eagle]], from [[The Muppets]], replacing [[Frank Oz]] beginning in 2001. Also replaced Oz in the roles of ''[[Sesame Street]]'''s [[Bert (Sesame Street)|Bert]] and [[Grover]] beginning in 1998 (However, Oz still occasionally returns to ''[[Sesame Street]]'' to perform these characters and ([[Cookie Monster]]) for fun).
